In the aftermath of the killing of George Floyd by Minneapolis police, school districts across the country – including in Minneapolis, Denver, and Seattle – have recognized the unintended consequences of having police in schools and have made a commitment to remove local police from schools.

It's time for Helena to do the same. Ask the Helena City Commission to remove police from public schools today!

Police don't belong in schools. Instead, students need access to teachers and well-trained mental health professionals to guide and support them through tough times. Responding to student misbehavior by criminalizing it only harms students, their families, and our communities.

National research, and our research here in Montana have shown that schools with police are not actually any safer for students. In fact, schools with police have higher rates of arrests, referrals to law enforcement, and out-of-school suspensions. And, what we've seen across the country is also true in Montana: Black, Indigenous, and other students of color experience disproportionate rates of punishment and police interactions.

Take Action

Police in schools are also expensive. The City of Helena currently pays $320,000 a year to fund police in Helena schools. That's a lot of money that could go a long way in ensuring that Helena is a safe and healthy community for all.

Ask the City Commission to divest the $320,000 they currently put toward police in Helena's schools and to reinvest it in services that would benefit the entire community.

The City Commission is meeting Monday, June 29, at 6 p.m., and is open to public comment on this issue. They need to hear from you. In addition to sending them an email, you can join the meeting and voice your support for removing police from Helena's schools. Just click this link at 6 on Monday to join. Please note: This link will take you to a third-party website, zoom.com

It's time to divest from the systems that criminalize students and reallocate that money to services that help the entire community – including students – thrive.

Helena can be a leader in this movement and the state. Email the City Commission today.
